bibl.title: Letter from Sarah Hinds Wilder to Henry Rose Carter, December 26, 1915

div1.p: Wilder expresses her appreciation for Carter's work.

div1.head: Letter from Sarah Hinds Wilder to Henry Rose Carter, December 26, 1915
div1.opener:
1895 Thorburn Avenue
Portland - Oregon-
Dr. Henry R. Carter-
Kind Sir-
div1.p:
I believe God is “good
to us both-” Evidently he has given
you a daughter - who realizes her
blessing in having a father-like
you - to care for while I have a son
who quite shamelessly spoils
his silly old mother-

I could never tell you my surprise
when I read your letter- I had been
wondering if you were yet alive in
Porto Rico - never dreaming you could
have returned home - or that you
would trouble to write-

It seems that I owed you more
than I knew- It was you who
made Sra. Paquita -- the proprie-
tress of the Hotel Yumari - relent-
when she tried to charge me $500
for the 5 days Mr Wilder was ill- Not Sra.
Yametti - she was Nueva Cubana- I wrote to
her for several years and her daughter spent
a Summer with us in the East when the
Worcester girls did themselves proved in
entertaining her- She said she didn't know
girls could have such good times- But Sra.
Paquita -- I remember standing on the
opposite side of the court - with the New
England doctor who was your assistant-
when she gave me the bill and poured
out a steady stream of Spanish invectins
all the time you and the Cuban doctors
were embalming Mr. Wilder's body- I often
wondered what softened her heart- I
did not know of the attachment and I
realize now that you probably saved me
from a very unpleasant experience - and
I thank you sincerely- So “Gorgas did
most of it-” It maybe that unselfish kindness
is an integral part of his character too-
You speak of Panama and Russia- I
always thought of you as somewhere in
the thick of the fight in Panama - and
I believe - I saw your name mentioned
in connection with the Russian party -
yet- regardless of press notices is the fact
that the worker who keeps the light burn-
ing is quite as necessary for the true
enlightenment of the world as is the
lamp or its reflector-

You certainly have had a “strenous”
life-

They say this higher steeps are gen-
erally rocky- Still it must be pleas-
ant to stand where the far-reaching
results of one's efforts can be seen-
You honor my note too much - but
I shall keep your letter as I have
your card and that of Dr Finley - through
all these years - and when I begin to lose
faith in humanity- I shall read -
and remember there still are
men who realize that the individ-
ual consciousness of having
done one's duty is the greatest
earthly reward.

May the New Year bring you
health -- and happiness both
to you and yours-
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours Sarah Hinds Wilder December 26th 1915
